page.title: List of Nobel laureates affiliated with the University of Pennsylvania

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead.) #IABot (v2.0
revision.text:
{{see also|List of Nobel laureates by university affiliation}} [[Image:Benjamin Franklin statue in front of College Hall.JPG|thumb|250px|Twenty-eight Nobel laureates have been affiliated with the [[University of Pennsylvania]]. Pictured is the statue of [[Benjamin Franklin]], the founder of the University of Pennsylvania, in front of [[College Hall (University of Pennsylvania)|College Hall]].]] The [[Nobel Prize]]s are awarded annually by the [[Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences]], the [[Karolinska Institute]], and the [[Norwegian Nobel Committee]] to individuals who make outstanding contributions in the fields of [[Nobel Prize in Chemistry|chemistry]], [[Nobel Prize in Physics|physics]], [[Nobel Prize in Literature|literature]], [[Nobel Peace Prize|peace]], and [[Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine|physiology or medicine]].<ref>{{cite web | title = Alfred Nobel – The Man Behind the Nobel Prize | publisher = [[Nobel Foundation]] | url = http://nobelprize.org/alfred_nobel/|accessdate=2008-10-20}}</ref> They were established by the 1895 will of [[Alfred Nobel]], which dictates that the awards should be administered by the [[Nobel Foundation]]. Another prize, the [[Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences]], was established in 1968 by the [[Sveriges Riksbank]], the [[central bank]] of [[Sweden]], for contributors to the field of economics.<ref name="NobelPrizeDescription">{{cite web|url=http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/|title=The Nobel Prize|publisher=[[Nobel Foundation]]|accessdate=2008-10-20}}</ref> Each prize is awarded by a separate committee; the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences awards the Prizes in Physics, Chemistry, and Economics, the Karolinska Institute awards the Prize in Physiology or Medicine, and the Norwegian Nobel Committee awards the Prize in Peace.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Nobel Prize Awarders |publisher=[[Nobel Foundation]] |url=http://nobelprize.org/prize_awarders/ |accessdate=2008-10-20 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081015013145/http://nobelprize.org/prize_awarders/ |archivedate=October 15, 2008 }}</ref> Each recipient receives a medal, a diploma and a cash prize that has varied throughout the years.<ref name="NobelPrizeDescription"/> In 1901, the winners of the first Nobel Prizes were given 150,782 [[Swedish krona|SEK]], which is equal to 7,731,004 SEK in December 2007. In 2008, the winners were awarded a prize amount of 10,000,000 SEK.<ref>{{cite web | title = The Nobel Prize Amounts | publisher = [[Nobel Foundation]] | url = http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/amounts.html|accessdate=2008-10-20 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080731233358/http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/amounts.html <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2008-07-31}}</ref> The awards are presented in [[Stockholm]] in an annual ceremony on December 10, the [[anniversary]] of Nobel's death.<ref>{{cite web | title = The Nobel Prize Award Ceremonies | publisher = [[Nobel Foundation]] | url = http://nobelprize.org/award_ceremonies/|accessdate=2008-10-20 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080822184717/http://nobelprize.org/award_ceremonies/ <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2008-08-22}}</ref>
As of 2015, there have been 28 laureates affiliated with the [[University of Pennsylvania]], 6 alone in the last 10 years. The University of Pennsylvania considers laureates who attended the university as undergraduate students, graduate students or were members of the faculty as affiliated laureates.<ref name="UPennLaureates">{{cite web|url=http://www.archives.upenn.edu/people/notables/awards/nobel.html|title=Nobel Laureates at Penn|publisher=[[University of Pennsylvania]]|accessdate=2008-10-20|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131103064008/http://www.archives.upenn.edu/people/notables/awards/nobel.html|archive-date=2013-11-03|url-status=dead}}</ref> [[Otto Fritz Meyerhof]], a research professor in physiological chemistry, was the first University of Pennsylvania laureate, winning the [[Nobel Prize in Chemistry]] in 1922.<ref name="Medicine1922">{{cite web|url = http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/medicine/laureates/1922/index.html|title=Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine 1922|accessdate=2008-10-20|publisher = [[Nobel Foundation]]}}</ref> Two Nobel Prizes were shared by University of Pennsylvania laureates; [[Ragnar Granit]] and [[Haldan Keffer Hartline]] won the 1967 Nobel Prize in Chemistry,<ref name="Medicine1967">{{cite web|url = http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/medicine/laureates/1967/index.html|title=Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine 1967|accessdate=2008-10-20|publisher = [[Nobel Foundation]]}}</ref> and [[Alan J. Heeger]], [[Alan MacDiarmid]] and [[Hideki Shirakawa]] won the 2000 Nobel Prize in Chemistry.<ref name="Chemistry2000">{{cite web | title = The Nobel Prize in Chemistry 2000| publisher = [[Nobel Foundation]] | url = http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/chemistry/laureates/2000/index.html|accessdate=2008-10-20}}</ref> Three laureates, [[Christian B. Anfinsen]], [[Gerald Edelman]], and [[John Robert Schrieffer]], won different Nobel Prizes in 1972, and were awarded an honorary [[Doctor of Science]] degree in 1973.<ref name="UPennLaureates"/> Nine University of Pennsylvania laureates have won the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine, more than any other category.<ref name="UPennLaureates"/>
==Laureates== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width:98%; background:#fff;" |- ! Year !! class="unsortable" style="width:75px;"| Image !! Laureate !! Relation !! Category !! class="unsortable" | Rationale |- | style="text-align:center;"| 1922 | [[File:Otto Fritz Meyerhof.jpg|75px]] | {{sortname|Otto Fritz|Meyerhof}} | Research Professor in Physiological Chemistry, 1940–1951 | [[Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine|Physiology or Medicine]] | "for his discovery of the fixed relationship between the consumption of [[oxygen]] and the [[metabolism]] of [[lactic acid]] in the muscle"<ref name="Medicine1922"/> |- | style="text-align:center;"| 1938 | [[Image:Richard Kuhn ETH-Bib Dia 248-065.jpg|75px]] | {{sortname|Richard|Kuhn}} | Visiting Research Professor for [[Physiological chemistry]] | [[Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine|Physiology or Medicine]] | "for his work on [[carotenoids]] and [[vitamins]]"<ref name="Chemistry1938">{{cite web | title = The Nobel Prize in Chemistry 1938 | publisher = [[Nobel Foundation]] | url = http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/chemistry/laureates/1938/kuhn-bio.html|accessdate=2010-10-04}}</ref> |- | style="text-align:center;"| 1955 | [[Image:Dr. Vincent du Vigneaud.jpg|75px]] | {{sortname|Vincent|du Vigneaud}} | Assistant in Biochemistry, Graduate School of Medicine, 1924–1925 | [[Nobel Prize in Chemistry|Chemistry]] | "for his work on [[sulfur|sulphur]] compounds, especially the first synthesis of a [[polypeptide]] [[hormone]]"<ref name="Chemistry1955">{{cite web | title = The Nobel Prize in Chemistry 1955 | publisher = [[Nobel Foundation]] | url = http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/chemistry/laureates/1955/index.html|accessdate=2008-10-20}}</ref> |- | style="text-align:center;"| 1961 | [[Image:Robert Hofstadter.jpg|75px]] | {{sortname|Robert|Hofstadter}} | Research Fellow, 1939–1940; Physics Instructor, 1940–1941 | [[Nobel Prize in Physics|Physics]] | "for his pioneering studies of electron scattering in atomic nuclei and for his thereby achieved discoveries concerning the structure of the nucleons"<ref name="Physics1961">{{cite web | title = The Nobel Prize in Physics 1961 | publisher = [[Nobel Foundation]] | url = http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/physics/laureates/1961/index.html|accessdate=2008-10-09}}</ref> |- | style="text-align:center;"| 1964 |[[Image:Martin Luther King Jr NYWTS.jpg|75px]] | {{sortname|Martin Luther|King, Jr.}} | Graduate Student, 1950–51 | [[Nobel Peace Prize]] | for being "the first person in the Western world to have shown us that a struggle can be waged without violence."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/peace/laureates/1964/index.html |title=The Nobel Peace Prize 1964 |accessdate=2008-11-12|publisher=Nobel Foundation}}</ref> |- | style="text-align:center;"| 1967 | [[File:Ragnar Granit.jpg|75px]] | {{sortname|Ragnar|Granit}} | Research Fellow, 1929–1931; [[Doctor of Science|Sc.D.]], 1971 | [[Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine|Physiology or Medicine]] | "for their discoveries concerning the primary physiological and chemical visual processes in the [[human eye|eye]]"<ref name="Medicine1967"/> |- | style="text-align:center;"| 1967 | | {{sortname|Haldan Keffer|Hartline}} | Research Fellow in Biophysics, 1931–1936; Assistant Professor, 1936–1942; Associate Professor, 1943–1948; Professor, 1948–1949; Sc.D., 1971 | [[Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine|Physiology or Medicine]] | "for their discoveries concerning the primary physiological and chemical visual processes in the eye"<ref name="Medicine1967"/> |- | style="text-align:center;"| 1971 | | {{sortname|Simon|Kuznets}} | Assistant Professor of Economic Statistics, 1930–1934; Associate Professor, 1934–1935; Professor, 1936–1954; Sc.D., 1956; [[Doctor of Laws|LL.D.]], 1976 | [[Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences|Economics]] | "for his empirically founded interpretation of economic growth which has led to new and deepened insight into the economic and social structure and process of development."<ref name="Economics1971">{{cite web|url=http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/economics/laureates/1971/|title=The Sveriges Riksbank Prize in Economic Sciences in Memory of Alfred Nobel 1971|publisher=[[Nobel Foundation]]|accessdate=2008-10-20}}</ref> |- | style="text-align:center;"| 1972 | [[Image:Christian B. Anfinsen, NIH portrait, 1969.jpg|75px]] | {{sortname|Christian B.|Anfinsen}} | [[Master of Science|M.S.]], 1939; Sc.D., 1973 | [[Nobel Prize in Chemistry|Chemistry]] | "for his work on [[ribonuclease]], especially concerning the connection between the amino acid sequence and the biologically active conformation"<ref name="Chemistry1972">{{cite web | title = The Nobel Prize in Chemistry 1972 | publisher = [[Nobel Foundation]] | url = http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/chemistry/laureates/1972/index.html|accessdate=2008-10-20}}</ref> |- | style="text-align:center;"| 1972 | | {{sortname|Gerald|Edelman}} | [[Doctor of Medicine|M.D.]], 1954; Sc.D., 1973 | [[Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine|Physiology or Medicine]] | "for their discoveries concerning the chemical structure of [[antibodies]]"<ref name="Medicine1972">{{cite web|url = http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/medicine/laureates/1972/index.html|title=Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine 1972|accessdate=2008-10-20|publisher = [[Nobel Foundation]]}}</ref> |- | style="text-align:center;"| 1972 | [[Image:John Robert Schrieffer.jpg|75px]] | {{sortname|John Robert|Schrieffer}} | Professor of Physics, 1962–1980; Sc.D., 1973 | [[Nobel Prize in Physics|Physics]] | "for their jointly developed theory of [[superconductivity]], usually called the [[BCS-theory]]"<ref name="Physics1972">{{cite web | title = The Nobel Prize in Physics 1972 | publisher = [[Nobel Foundation]] | url = http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/physics/laureates/1972/index.html|accessdate=2008-10-20}}</ref> |- | style="text-align:center;"| 1976 | [[Image:Baruch Samuel Blumberg by Tom Trower (NASA).jpg|75px]] | {{sortname|Baruch Samuel|Blumberg}} | Professor of Medicine, 1964– ;Sc.D., 1990 | [[Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine|Physiology or Medicine]] | "for their discoveries concerning new mechanisms for the origin and dissemination of [[infectious disease]]s"<ref name="Medicine1976">{{cite web|url = http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/medicine/laureates/1976/index.html|title=Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine 1976|accessdate=2008-10-20|publisher = [[Nobel Foundation]]}}</ref> |- | style="text-align:center;"| 1980 | | {{sortname|Lawrence|Klein}} | Professor of Economics, 1958–1991 | [[Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences|Economics]] | "for the creation of [[econometry|econometric]] models and the application to the analysis of economic fluctuations and economic policies."<ref name="Economics1980">{{cite web|url=http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/economics/laureates/1980/|title=The Sveriges Riksbank Prize in Economic Sciences in Memory of Alfred Nobel 1980|publisher=[[Nobel Foundation]]|accessdate=2008-10-20}}</ref> |- | style="text-align:center;"| 1985 | [[Image:Mike Brown 2003.jpg|75px]] | {{sortname|Michael Stuart|Brown}} | [[Bachelor of Arts|A.B.]], 1962; M.D., 1966; Sc.D. 1986 | [[Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine|Physiology or Medicine]] | "for their discoveries concerning the regulation of [[cholesterol]] [[metabolism]]"<ref name="Medicine1980">{{cite web|url = http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/medicine/laureates/1980/index.html|title=Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine 1980|accessdate=2008-10-20|publisher = [[Nobel Foundation]]}}</ref> |- | style="text-align:center;"| 1997 | [[Image:Prusiner 1.JPG|75px]] | {{sortname|Stanley B.|Prusiner}} | A.B., 1964; M.D., 1968 | [[Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine|Physiology or Medicine]] | "for his discovery of [[Prion]]s - a new biological principle of infection"<ref name="Medicine1997">{{cite web|url = http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/medicine/laureates/1997/index.html|title=Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine 1997|accessdate=2008-10-20|publisher = [[Nobel Foundation]]}}</ref> |- | style="text-align:center;"| 1999 | [[Image:Ahmed_Zewail.jpg|75px]] | {{sortname|Ahmed|Zewail}} | [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]], 1974; Sc.D. 1997 | [[Nobel Prize in Chemistry|Chemistry]] | "for his studies of the transition states of chemical reactions using [[femtosecond]] [[spectroscopy]]"<ref name="Chemistry1999">{{cite web | title = The Nobel Prize in Chemistry 1999 | publisher = [[Nobel Foundation]] | url = http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/chemistry/laureates/1999/index.html|accessdate=2008-10-20}}</ref> |- | style="text-align:center;"| 2000 | | {{sortname|Alan J.|Heeger}} | Laboratory for Research on the Structure of Matter, 1962–1982 | [[Nobel Prize in Chemistry|Chemistry]] | "for their discovery and development of [[conductive polymer]]s"<ref name="Chemistry2000"/> |- | style="text-align:center;"| 2000 | | {{sortname|Alan|MacDiarmid}} | Department of Chemistry, 1955– ; Blanchard Professor of Chemistry, 1988– | [[Nobel Prize in Chemistry|Chemistry]] | "for their discovery and development of conductive polymers"<ref name="Chemistry2000"/> |- | style="text-align:center;"| 2000 | | {{sortname|Hideki|Shirakawa}} | Department of Chemistry, Post-Doctoral Researcher, 1976 | [[Nobel Prize in Chemistry|Chemistry]] | "for their discovery and development of conductive polymers"<ref name="Chemistry2000"/> |- | style="text-align:center;"| 2002 | [[File:Raymond Davis, Jr 2001.jpg|75px]] | {{sortname|Raymond|Davis, Jr.}} | Professor, 1985–2006 | [[Nobel Prize in Physics|Physics]] | "for pioneering contributions to astrophysics, in particular for the detection of cosmic [[neutrino]]s"<ref name="Physics2002">{{cite web | title = The Nobel Prize in Physics 2002 | publisher = [[Nobel Foundation]] | url = http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/physics/laureates/2002/index.html|accessdate=2008-10-20}}</ref> |- | style="text-align:center;"| 2004 | [[Image:Nobel2004chemistrylaurets-Rose.jpg|75px]] | {{sortname|Irwin|Rose}} | Professor of Physical Biochemistry, 1971– | [[Nobel Prize in Chemistry|Chemistry]] | "for the discovery of [[ubiquitin]]-mediated [[protein degradation]]"<ref name="Chemistry2004">{{cite web | title = The Nobel Prize in Chemistry 2004| publisher = [[Nobel Foundation]] | url = http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/chemistry/laureates/2004/index.html|accessdate=2008-10-20}}</ref> |- | style="text-align:center;"| 2004 | [[Image:Edward C. Prescott.jpg|75px]] | {{sortname|Edward C.|Prescott}} | Assistant Professor, 1967–1971 | [[Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences|Economics]] | "for their contributions to dynamic macroeconomics: the time consistency of economic policy and the driving forces behind [[business cycle]]s."<ref name="Economics2004">{{cite web|url=http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/economics/laureates/2004/|title=The Sveriges Riksbank Prize in Economic Sciences in Memory of Alfred Nobel 2004|publisher=[[Nobel Foundation]]|accessdate=2008-10-20}}</ref> |- | style="text-align:center;"| 2006 | [[Image:Edmund Phelps 2008-01-23.jpg|75px]] | {{sortname|Edmund|Phelps}} | Professor, 1966–1971 | [[Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences|Economics]] | "for his analysis of intertemporal tradeoffs in [[macroeconomic]] policy."<ref name="Economics2006">{{cite web|url=http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/economics/laureates/2006/|title=The Sveriges Riksbank Prize in Economic Sciences in Memory of Alfred Nobel 2006|publisher=[[Nobel Foundation]]|accessdate=2008-10-20}}</ref> |- | style="text-align:center;"| 2008 | [[Image:Harald zur Hausen-press conference Dec 06th, 2008-6.jpg|75px]] | {{sortname|Harald|zur Hausen}} | Assistant professor, 1968–1969<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dkfz.de/de/zurhausen/download/zh-cv.pdf |archive-url=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20090320002318/http://www.dkfz.de/de/zurhausen/download/zh-cv.pdf |url-status=dead |archive-date=2009-03-20 |title=Curriculum Vitae |last=zur Hausen |first=Harald |accessdate=2008-10-24 }}</ref> | [[Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine|Physiology or Medicine]] | "for his discovery of [[Human papillomavirus|human papilloma viruses]] causing [[cervical cancer]]"<ref name="medicine2008">{{cite web|url=http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/medicine/laureates/2008/|title=The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine 2008|publisher=[[Nobel Foundation]]|accessdate=2008-10-24}}</ref> |- | style="text-align:center;"| 2009 | [[Image:Nobel Prize 2009-Press Conference KVA-24.jpg|75px]] | {{sortname|George|E. Smith}} | B.S., 1955 | [[Nobel Prize in Physics|Physics]] | "for the invention of an imaging semiconductor circuit – the CCD sensor"<ref name="physics2009">{{cite web|url=http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/physics/laureates/2009/|title=The Nobel Prize in Physics 2009|publisher=[[Nobel Foundation]]|accessdate=2009-10-06}}</ref> |- | style="text-align:center;"| 2009 | [[Image:Nobel Prize 2009-Press Conference KVA-42.jpg|75px]] | {{sortname|Oliver |E. Williamson}} | Professor, 1965–1983 | [[Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences|Economics]] | "for his analysis of economic governance, especially the boundaries of the firm"<ref>{{Cite book | title = Sveriges Riksbank's Prize in Economic Sciences in Memory of Alfred Nobel 2009 | url = http://www.riksbank.com/templates/Page.aspx?id=20286 | publisher = Sveriges Riksbank | date = 12 October 2009 | accessdate = 2009-10-12 | url-status = dead | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20091017212331/http://www.riksbank.com/templates/Page.aspx?id=20286 | archivedate = 17 October 2009 }}</ref> |- | style="text-align:center;"| 2010 | [[Image:Ei-ichi Negishi 3.jpg|75px]] | {{sortname|Ei'ichi|Negishi}} | Ph.D., 1963 | [[Nobel Prize in Chemistry|Chemistry]] | "for palladium-catalyzed cross couplings in organic synthesis"<ref>{{Cite book | title = The Nobel Prize in Chemistry 2010 | url = http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/chemistry/laureates/2010/ | publisher = [[Nobel Foundation]] | date = 6 October 2010 | accessdate = 2010-10-06}}</ref> |- | style="text-align:center;"| 2011 | [[File:Nobel Prize 2011-Press Conference KVA-DSC 7770.jpg|75px]] | {{sortname|Thomas J.|Sargent}} | Professor, 1970–1971 | [[Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences|Economics]] | "for their empirical research on cause and effect in the macroeconomy" |- | style="text-align:center;"| 2019 | | [[Gregg L. Semenza]] | MD, PhD, 1984<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://hub.jhu.edu/2016/09/13/gregg-semenza-wins-lasker-award/|title=Johns Hopkins geneticist Gregg Semenza wins Lasker Award for insights into how cells sense oxygen|date=September 13, 2016|website=The Hub}}</ref> | [[Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine|Physiology or Medicine]] | "for discoveries of how cells sense and adapt to oxygen availability""<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2019/10/07/health/nobel-prize-for-medicine-2019-intl/index.html|title=Nobel Prize in Medicine awarded for new discovery on how humans respond to oxygen|first=Aimee|last=Lewis|website=CNN}}</ref> |}
